thread.title: President Trump finally denounces anti-Semitism

author: JASON SILVERSTEIN
title: President Trump finally denounces anti-Semitism
text:
22 AM 
President Trump has finally shared some thoughts about anti-Semitism: He doesn’t like it. 
Trump on Tuesday made his first public comments as President denouncing anti-Semitism — after sidestepping several high-profile opportunities to do so. 
His comments came a day after the fourth wave this year of hoax bomb threats made to Jewish community centers nationwide. 
“Anti-Semitism is horrible and it’s going to stop and it has to stop,” Trump said during a visit to the Smithsonian   and Culture. 
Someone at the museum asked if that meant Trump was denouncing anti-Semitism once and for all. 
“Oh, of course,” Trump said. 
“And I do it wherever I get a chance, I do it.” 
In fact, Trump has avoided each chance offered to him so far in office to speak out against anti-Semitism actions — which by some measures have spiked since Trump became President.

Trump made no mention of Jews in a statement for International Holocaust Remembrance Day, an omission the Anti-Defamation League called “puzzling and troubling.” The White House defended Trump’s vague statement, with Press Secretary Sean Spicer calling criticism of it “ridiculous” and “nitpicking.” “Anti-Semitism is horrible and it’s going to stop,” President Trump tells NBC News’ @craigmelvin https://t.co/kDXrgRz879 — MSNBC (@MSNBC) February 21, 2017 
Trump also avoided two chances at recent press conferences to speak directly about anti-Semitism. 
When asked about it during a joint presser with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Trump boasted about his election victory and simply noted that his daughter Ivanka is married to a Jewish man, Jared Kushner. 
“As far as people, Jewish people, so many friends, a daughter who happens to be here right now, a son-in-law,” Trump said. 
  
“I think a lot of good things are happening and you’re going to see a lot of love.” 
At a solo presser last week, a Jewish reporter for the Orthodox weekly Ami Magazine started asking Trump why he hadn’t address “an uptick in anti-Semitism and how the government is planning to take care of it.” 
Trump cut the reporter off, saying it was “not a fair question,” and told the reporter to sit down. 
He then christened himself “the least anti-Semitic person that you’ve ever seen in your entire life” and later accused his “opponents” of spreading anti-Semitism. 
During his campaign, Trump attracted support from several anti-Semitic groups, including the American Nazi Party. Tags:
